author: Judsonr
title: Bought it for the minifig, glad to have the minifig
review: Saw this in the store a couple of times before actually purchasing it.  I wanted the Thanos minifig, and it's really the highlight of this set.  I'm not a fan of the "mechs," but it had some new parts in new colors for my collection.  The minifig's helmet may be the best part of the complete set.  The set is basically $10 for a unique minfig and some good parts

author: Bhahouighf
title: As fun as it is funny
review:
I've seen Infinity War and Endgame, and I enjoy the MCU's depiction of Thanos very much; however, I am but a lad, and I have been moulded by the digital era, so I recognize Thanos first and foremost as a bit of a meme. As such, rather than being alienated by a concept as irreverent as Thanos Mech, its inherent hilariousness was enough to pique my curiosity. Thankfully, I am not the least bit disappointed with this purchase, and in fact I found myself compelled to write to you all so that you, too, may share in my delight.

Parts and Minifigure

I like this Thanos minifigure. The use of Vladek's helmet to stand in for his distinctive helm is probably disappointing to a lot of people, but I am not one of them, because I prefer his look without the helmet and the minifigure designer had the forethought to leave the back of his head unprinted so that he may be displayed sans headgear. I also now have a golden version of Vladek's helmet to use on whatever I please, so that's a win for me. The minifigure isn't anything special in terms of print detail or quality, but it's special to me because it's Thanos and I love him.

As far as parts go, the most notable are the large mech chestplate element in gold, which I believe only appears elsewhere in 2018's Tech Wizard Showdown, the printed shield piece which provides the chest's detail, and the ten drum-lacquered gold parts, comprising two 1x1 tiles, five 1x1 cheese slopes, two 2x2 cut-corner tiles, and one 3x3 dish. Make of the parts what you will; I don't know if any of those are in high demand, but you might! 

The Build

I cannot say that I had very much fun building Thanos Mech. I wouldn't call it a bad build, but it has many small parts and there are multiple 1x1 pieces that, if you're like me, you'll spend excessive time and effort on aligning. Building and straightening the fingers is also a little tedious, though not terribly so, and I winced a little every time I had to touch one of the drum-lacquered gold parts because I'm horribly afraid of wearing down the finish. Those on the younger side probably won't be as worried about the fine details as I was, but they may have difficulty with some of the more delicate sections of the building process, so I can't say I expect anyone to really love building this set.

Play and Display Potential

The mech is nice looking! The sides are gappy, and it obviously doesn't have accurate human proportions, but it's a nice looking mech, and it doesn't take a great stretch of the imagination to see it simply as a large, tiny-headed Thanos. Its many points of articulation make it great for posing, but if play gets too rough, the mech's joints are likely to be jostled into some unusual positions. It's also very easy to modify because its construction is so simple; I've swapped the large golden chestplate element for a dark blue version, which I think creates a more cohesive look and evokes Thanos's appearance in Avengers: Infinity War. 

The biggest obstacle to play here is that this is only a Thanos Mech. Now, while I'm perfectly content with solo Thanos adventures, some kids may want to make the Thanos Mech fight people, but foes are tragically absent from this set. For solo play with Thanos Mech, I suggest flinging the Infinity Stones off somewhere in a carpeted room and trying to hunt them back down or pretending the Mad Titan is giving a monologue after wiping out all life in the vicinity.

Overall Thoughts

Thanos Mech is not a technical marvel. It doesn't really stand out from its three counterparts by its own merit, so I imagine purchases will be driven by the popularity of its pilot. This was the case for me, and I am satisfied with the Thanos I have purchased. That is why, although I can't honestly give Thanos Mech a 5 in all categories, I rate it five stars overall. It's also worth noting that the Marvel mechs probably have the most Fun Potential out of all the sub-series of $10 knick-knacks LEGO has released this year, as the Friends and Ninjago pods are mostly focused on storage. In conclusion, I recommend Thanos Mech to you and all of your friends!

author: TheMasksYT39
title: Best Mech Out Of The Marvel Mechs (For Now)
review: Minifigure: The Thanos Minifigure Is Great. I Just Wish LEGO Would Make Printed Hands So They Could Print The Gauntlet. Build: The Build Is Great I Like How You Can Make The Snapping Pose With The Gauntlet Playability: There Is No Playability At All In This Set (Well Unless You Count Posing As Playability But I Count That As Displayability) Value For Money: This Set Is Not Overpriced,Its Underpriced. I Would Pay $15 Instead Of $10

author: Spruce
title: Thanos Mech (I can't say that without laughing), LEGO set 76141
review:
Pre-Release Thoughts

A Thanos mech? But why? These are the questions that were going through my head the moment I heard about this. The absurdity of something like this is what I live for. By the time it released, my curiosity had gotten the best of me and I bought it.

Build Experience + Model

The build experience was almost surreal. “I'm building an armored suit for a purple titan” kept going through my head.

Obviously the model was pretty short. I expected that, as it is a $10 set. Even with its small proportions, I feel that this model manages to be everything I could ask for from a mech. The body is connected mainly by using Mixel ball joints. The standout feature here is the Infinity Gauntlet, using a mix of dark tan, drum lacquer gold, and warm gold. The Infinity stones look perfect and still manage to allow for good articulation. 

The cockpit is built using a new piece to hold the minifigure in, but Thanos tends to slip out.

Minifigure

Thanos is here! He looks great for a comic book accurate figure. This minifigure is perfectly fitting for this set and I couldn't ask for more.

Value

For $10, this certainly gives you a substantial mech. The play and display value is good here, as well as the price per part ratio and the volume for price value. This also has the additional meme value. A Thanos mech is such a hilariously weird idea that will surely get a laugh out of you once you have it in hand.

Overall

This set is an absolute joke. Come on, a Thanes mech? It's absolutely crazy. However, the set manages to be superb for play. I'd highly recommend it to Marvel fans and general Lego fans.

- Christmaskingcool
